pageContext.description: Cast copper alloy palstave dating from the Middle Bronze Age, i.e. c. 1500-1300BC. The axe is a heavy implement for its size and complete with the two flanges and a crescent-shaped blade with up-turned corners. It is part of the Taunton metalwork assemblage. The axe has two triangular flanges (diamond-shaped from the side). The casting flashes are visible and have been filed but are still slightly raised and with its small, worn semi-circular stop-ridge it could be related to the shield-pattern palstaves of the Acton Park metalwork assemblage to which it bears some resemblance. It has a dull brown patina. The axe blade is bevelled and appears to have been re-sharpened. The patina is a dull blackish-green. A similar, less complete palstave was recorded here: LANCUM-F8B182. The length is 158mm, the width is 72mm, thickness 50mm and the weight too heavy for scales.
